content: I am 37 years old and had been trying to enlist in the WA arng. I had to have several medical waivers approved which I did over the course of 2 years. At the point of enlisting (I was actually signing the electronic signature pad) the arng liason who was working with me noticed I needed one more waiver. It was a moral waiver for some past drug use I did over 10 years ago. He said it would pass no problem I'll just have to wait about 4 more weeks. Ok no problem I thought, I'd come this far. Well about 3 weeks later my recruiter called and told me they lowered the age limit from 42 to 35! Is that correct? I worked for 2 years to get in and jumped through tons of hoops only to be told the age limit has gone down! The recruiter said even all those waiting on waivers were denied! WTF! What I really want to know is that correct and is it the same for the reserves or other branches? Please help me out i've tried too hard only to be turned down after 2 years.

content: Yes. It reverted back to 35 on 23 March. They changed it from 35 to 40 in 2006, and then they raised it to 42 not long after that. But now it has gone back to 35. You must be IN Basic by that age, ie: not just signed up, but serving your first day. This is for non-prior service - prior service stayed the same, age 43. It sucks ballz that you went through all this trouble just to get hit with last month's decision to lower the age standards back to pre-2006. I am so sorry, my friend. Still, you MAY be able to get an age waiver based on the fact that you have been in the system before the change. I don't know that you can, but if I were in your shoes I'd be demanding one for all the effort already put in. Let us know how it goes, ok? Remember, where one recruiter won't do for you, there are a million more that might. Don't stop looking at different recruiters until you find the one that will do anything to sign you up. It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.
